title: I quit my job at JPMorgan to run a restaurant group with my dad. It's the best decision I've ever made.
summary:
Photo courtesy of The Louis CollectionKassidy Angelo is pictured with her father, Tom Angelo.
I never imagined myself entering the restaurant business at the age of 24.
I viewed it as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity not only to work with my dad, but to build something from the ground up.
Having worked with senior management at JPMorgan, I had the confidence to run the restaurant.
On my first day at the restaurant, I learned how to run the door, be a hostess, serve, and run private events.

title: How banning big investors from buying homes could affect prices
summary:
Industry watchers on both sides of the aisle say President Donald Trump's recently announced goal of banning "large institutional investors" from buying single-family homes won't address the root cause of high home prices: a shortage of homes.
In the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, large investors bought thousands of distressed properties, particularly in Southeastern cities.
And since 2022, large investors have slowed their purchasing as interest rates have spiked and home prices have remained high.
Some major investors have shifted their business model to buying homes in bulk directly from homebuilders, rather than purchasing them one by one.
Fairweather agreed that banning large landlords from owning single-family homes would mean fewer tenants could live in these wealthier neighborhoods.

Trump also wants to lower interest rates to around 1% or less, essentially making that a requirement of the next Fed Chair.
What the 1970s taught us is that there is good economic growth and bad economic “growth,” called inflation.
It is very possible that Trump drops the Fed Funds Rate to 1%, and broader interest rates rise in response.

title: Looking for a Job? These Cities Are Leading the Way in 2026
summary:
MORE THAN A PAYCHECKWalletHubThere are two key drivers when it comes to uncovering the cities with the best job opportunities in 2026: market and socioeconomic factors.
According to WalletHub, job market factors to consider when searching for your next best role include employment growth, average monthly salary, unemployment rates, job security, job satisfaction, and access to benefits and retirement options.
Columbia, Maryland, quietly dominates with promising employment growth, affordable rent and housing, and exceptional job security.
Down South, Orlando, Florida, is not just tourists and theme parks; it's a thriving job market paired with no state income tax, which is always a plus.
This metropolis reported robust job growth from 2024 to 2026 across multiple specialties and annual median wages that align with the rising cost of living.

title: Hiring slows in December to end the weakest year of job growth since the pandemic
summary:
Hiring slows in December to end the weakest year of job growth since the pandemictoggle caption Spencer Platt/Getty Images North AmericaHiring remained anemic in December, closing out the weakest year for job growth since the beginning of the pandemic.
For all of 2025, employers added 584,000 jobs — compared to 2 million new jobs in 2024.
The federal government added 2,000 jobs in December, but is still down 277,000 jobs from the beginning of the year.
The government recorded big job losses earlier in the fall, when workers who accepted buyouts officially dropped off the government's payroll.
Concern about the weakening job market prompted the Federal Reserve to cut its benchmark interest rate in December for the third time since September.

Proponents of prediction markets argue putting money on the line leads to better forecasts.
Still, it's never a “crystal ball,” he noted, and prediction markets can be wrong, too.

title: Canadian economy added 8,200 jobs in December, while unemployment rose to 6.8%
summary:
Statistics Canada says a boost in the number of people looking for work in December drove the unemployment rate higher at the end of the year.
Canada created just 8,200 new jobs in December, while the unemployment rate rose to 6.8 per cent, up from 6.5 per cent the month before.
December's job gains were concentrated in full-time work, which added 50,200 jobs in December, while part-time ‍employment fell ⁠by 42,000.
Douglas Porter, BMO's chief economist, said the December figures bring job gains back to a more "realistic place."
Friday's jobs report marks the Bank of Canada's last look at the state of the labour market before its first interest-rate decision of the year later this month.

When I speak to Mahan, he emphasizes the risk of California standing alone in taxing the net worth of billionaires.
Because of the mobility of rich people, California does have real worries about the impact of a state wealth tax.
Also, I don’t see why an exodus of billionaires necessarily means the end of Silicon Valley as the heart of tech innovation.
A few years ago, some tech people moved to Miami, claiming it was going to become the new Silicon Valley.

title: Ford Stored Unsold Mavericks Underground in Kansas City During 1970s Sales Slump
summary:
During the 1970s, Ford Motor Company took an unconventional approach to managing surplus inventory by storing unsold vehicles deep underground beneath Kansas City.
As market conditions shifted and sales slowed, Ford found itself with thousands of unsold Mavericks occupying dealership space and storage lots.
Compared with surface storage, the underground environment lowered long-term storage costs and preserved vehicle condition while Ford evaluated its next steps.
By storing completed vehicles underground, Ford effectively bought time to redistribute inventory or sell cars later once demand stabilized.
Rather than forcing rapid discounting or scrapping new vehicles, Ford used the underground storage as a buffer against shifting consumer demand.

and international oil companies to discuss ‌potential investment in Venezuela’s energy sector, as the administration weighs ways to revive crude output in the ⁠sanctions-hit country, ‌according to a White House official.
